Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Mobile Flow Cytometry and Cell Sorting Facility for Microbiological Research and Minority Student Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI's requests MRI funding to acquire a mobile facility for flow cytometry and cell sorting analysis of microorganisms and training of students, including underrepresented minority undergraduate and graduate students. This mobile facility will form the core of a collaborative resource center to enable students and researchers at UCI and other research institutions to rapidly analyze both very small microbes (e.g. bacteria or viruses) as well as larger protozoa such as Toxoplasma gondii. The mobile capacity will allow researchers to sort live populations at the sampling site (e.g., at sea). The facility will be used primarily for research in three areas: 1) bacterial genomics and in situ physiology, 2) viral abundance and interaction with marine host bacteria, and 3) interactive parasite/host evolution studies.

Broader Impacts:

A particular strength of the proposal is its integration of student training programs at UCI to include flow cytometry and environmental microbiology. The inclusion of Dr. Mota-Bravo as the director of the Minority Science Program should ensure success in attracting and training students from underrepresented groups. The proposed equipment will also strengthen the infrastructure for an array of environmental microbiology programs directed by investigators in 6 departments at UCI, and collaborators at USC, so the impact of its availability is high.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award allowed us to establish a state-of-the-art flow cytometry facility at University of California, Irvine (UCI) dedicated to microbiology research. The funds enabled us to purchase a BD InFlux cell-sorter and a BD Accuri C6 flow cytometer analyzer. The facility facilitated new research in the areas of phytoplankton biology and biogeochemistry, marine virus diversity, leaf litter microbial ecology, and broadly introduced flow cytometry in diverse areas of science. A constant Carbon:Nitrogen:Phosphorus ratio of surface plankton of 106:16:1 (also called the Redfield ratio) represents a central tenet for our understanding of ocean biogeochemistry. In a series of studies using the flow cytometry instruments, we have demonstrated that the elemental composition of marine plankton varies depending on cellular growth conditions. We have further shown that the elemental composition varies between plankton lineages as well as temporally in the field depending on environmental conditions and plankton community composition. We have also developed a new experimental approach using flow cytometry to quantify bacteria in leaf litter. This new approach has been applied to understand how plant litter microbial communities respond to possible future global changes in nutrient and water availability. Finally, we have developed new cell-sorting techniques enabling us to quantify the plankton host range of marine viruses.

The facility has had broad impact on science done by students and researchers at UCI as well as the surrounding community. Our new facility has enabled us to greatly advance our understanding of how marine communities of influence biogeochemical cycling in the ocean. We have also greatly advanced our understanding of how microorganisms contribute to plant material degradation. In addition to these studies, the new flow cytometry facility at UCI has been extremely popular and the instruments have been used by a wide-range of researchers at UCI and surrounding institutions and local businesses. Thus, many students and researchers have been introduced to and trained in flow cytometry techniques as a result of this award.
